title: History of Present Illness
content: The patient is here for follow-up and reports recurrent pain and stiffness in both thumbs. He notes that the right thumb symptoms recurred a few weeks ago, with increasing stiffness, swelling, and reduced range of motion. He describes pain along the radial border of the left thumb, starting at the wrist and extending to the tip. The symptoms are persistent and have been progressively affecting function. The patient attributes the onset to repetitive use of a computer, which he confirms was the same device used during his prior evaluation. He has previously received an injection for the right thumb with temporary relief. No other aggravating or relieving factors were reported. The symptoms are impacting daily activities, particularly fine motor tasks involving the hands.

title: Assessment and Plan
content: Assessment: The patient has recurrent bilateral thumb pain consistent with De Quervain's tenosynovitis, with more pronounced symptoms on the right side. The presence of a palpable nodule at the A1 pulley with triggering on the right, along with tenderness at the radial styloid on the left, supports the diagnosis. The patient had temporary relief from a prior injection, indicating a positive response to treatment. No signs of systemic illness or other underlying conditions are present.

Plan: Initiate a second corticosteroid injection into the right thumb A1 pulley for symptomatic relief. Recommend a home exercise program focused on thumb and wrist stretching and strengthening to improve function and reduce inflammation. Advise patient to avoid repetitive gripping and prolonged computer use without ergonomic adjustments. Provide education on activity modification and the importance of adherence to the exercise regimen. No new medications prescribed. No immediate surgical intervention indicated at this time.
